sub_topic: Calculating the percent composition of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the percentage composition of magnesium chloride (MgCl2)? Show the steps you took to arrive at your answer.
message_2:
To find the percentage composition of magnesium chloride (MgCl2), we need to determine the molar mass of the compound and then find the mass percentage of each element (magnesium and chlorine) in the compound.

Step 1: Determine the molar mass of MgCl2
The molar mass of a compound is the sum of the molar masses of its constituent elements. The molar mass of magnesium (Mg) is 24.305 g/mol, and the molar mass of chlorine (Cl) is 35.453 g/mol.

MgCl2 = 1 Mg atom + 2 Cl atoms
Molar mass of MgCl2 = (1 × 24.305 g/mol) + (2 × 35.453 g/mol)
Molar mass of MgCl2 = 24.305 g/mol + 70.906 g/mol
Molar mass of MgCl2 = 95.211 g/mol

Step 2: Calculate the mass percentage of each element
Now we will find the mass percentage of magnesium and chlorine in MgCl2.

Mass percentage of Mg = (molar mass of Mg / molar mass of MgCl2) × 100
Mass percentage of Mg = (24.305 g/mol / 95.211 g/mol) × 100
Mass percentage of Mg ≈ 25.53%

Mass percentage of Cl = (molar mass of Cl / molar mass of MgCl2) × 100
Since there are 2 Cl atoms in MgCl2, we need to multiply the molar mass of Cl by 2.
Mass percentage of Cl = (70.906 g/mol / 95.211 g/mol) × 100
Mass percentage of Cl ≈ 74.47%

The percentage composition of magnesium chloride (MgCl2) is approximately 25.53% magnesium (Mg) and 74.47% chlorine (Cl).
